trans-unit.source: Upgrade SQL Database Web or Business Databases to New Service Tiers
trans-unit.target: Upgrade SQL Database Web or Business Databases to New Service Tiers

trans-unit.source: Upgrade Azure SQL Database Web or Business databases to the new Azure SQL Database Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers and performance levels.
trans-unit.target: Upgrade Azure SQL Database Web or Business databases to the new Azure SQL Database Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers and performance levels.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Web and Business databases are being deprecated and <linkText>retired September 2015</linkText><title></title> so it's time to start planning to upgrade existing Web or Business databases to the Basic, Standard, or Premium service tiers.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Web and Business databases are being deprecated and <linkText>retired September 2015</linkText><title></title> so it's time to start planning to upgrade existing Web or Business databases to the Basic, Standard, or Premium service tiers.

trans-unit.source: Download the [Web and Business Database Migration Guidance Cookbook](http://download.microsoft.com/download/3/C/9/3C9FF3D8-E702-4F5D-A38C-5EFA1DBA73E6/AzureSQLDatabaseMigrationCookbook.pdf).
trans-unit.target: Download the [Web and Business Database Migration Guidance Cookbook](http://download.microsoft.com/download/3/C/9/3C9FF3D8-E702-4F5D-A38C-5EFA1DBA73E6/AzureSQLDatabaseMigrationCookbook.pdf).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Pricing tier recommendations</linkText><title></title> for Web and Business databases are now available.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Pricing tier recommendations</linkText><title></title> for Web and Business databases are now available.

trans-unit.source: Azure Web and Business SQL databases run in a shared, multi-tenant environment without any reserved resource capacity for the database. The activity of other databases within this shared resource environment can impact your performance. Resource availability at any given point depends heavily on other concurrent workloads running in the system. This can result in highly varying and unpredictable database application performance. Customer feedback is that this unpredictable performance is difficult to manage, and more predictable performance is preferred.
trans-unit.target: Azure Web and Business SQL databases run in a shared, multi-tenant environment without any reserved resource capacity for the database. The activity of other databases within this shared resource environment can impact your performance. Resource availability at any given point depends heavily on other concurrent workloads running in the system. This can result in highly varying and unpredictable database application performance. Customer feedback is that this unpredictable performance is difficult to manage, and more predictable performance is preferred.

trans-unit.source: To address this feedback, Azure SQL Database service introduced new database service tiers <linkText>(Basic, Standard and Premium)</linkText><title></title>, which offer predictable performance and a wealth of new features for business continuity and security.
trans-unit.target: To address this feedback, Azure SQL Database service introduced new database service tiers <linkText>(Basic, Standard and Premium)</linkText><title></title>, which offer predictable performance and a wealth of new features for business continuity and security.

trans-unit.source: These new service tiers are designed to provide a specified level of resources for a database workload, regardless of other customer workloads running in that environment.
trans-unit.target: These new service tiers are designed to provide a specified level of resources for a database workload, regardless of other customer workloads running in that environment.

trans-unit.source: This results in highly predictable performance behavior.
trans-unit.target: This results in highly predictable performance behavior.

trans-unit.source: With these changes come questions about how to evaluate and decide which new service tier is the best fit for current Web and Business (W/B) databases and about the actual upgrade process.
trans-unit.target: With these changes come questions about how to evaluate and decide which new service tier is the best fit for current Web and Business (W/B) databases and about the actual upgrade process.

trans-unit.source: Ultimately, the best choice is the service tier and performance level combination that provides you the optimum balance between features, performance, and cost, yet one which completely satisfies the business needs and requirements of your application.
trans-unit.target: Ultimately, the best choice is the service tier and performance level combination that provides you the optimum balance between features, performance, and cost, yet one which completely satisfies the business needs and requirements of your application.

trans-unit.source: This paper provides a guided methodology for upgrading a Web or Business database to one of the new service tiers/performance levels.
trans-unit.target: This paper provides a guided methodology for upgrading a Web or Business database to one of the new service tiers/performance levels.

trans-unit.source: What is important to note, is that Azure SQL Databases are not locked into any specific service tier or performance level, so as the requirements of your database change you can easily change between the available service tiers and performance levels.
trans-unit.target: What is important to note, is that Azure SQL Databases are not locked into any specific service tier or performance level, so as the requirements of your database change you can easily change between the available service tiers and performance levels.

trans-unit.source: In fact, Basic, Standard, and Premium SQL Databases are billed by the hour, and you have the ability to scale each database up or down 4 times within a 24 hour period (using the <linkText>Azure Portal or programmatically</linkText><title></title>).
trans-unit.target: In fact, Basic, Standard, and Premium SQL Databases are billed by the hour, and you have the ability to scale each database up or down 4 times within a 24 hour period (using the <linkText>Azure Portal or programmatically</linkText><title></title>).

trans-unit.source: This means you can adjust the service tier and performance level to maximize your database’s performance needs, feature set, and cost, based on your application’s requirements and varying workload.
trans-unit.target: This means you can adjust the service tier and performance level to maximize your database’s performance needs, feature set, and cost, based on your application’s requirements and varying workload.

trans-unit.source: This also means that evaluating and changing the service tier and performance level of your database (scaling up and down) is an ongoing process that should be part of your scheduled maintenance and performance tuning routine.
trans-unit.target: This also means that evaluating and changing the service tier and performance level of your database (scaling up and down) is an ongoing process that should be part of your scheduled maintenance and performance tuning routine.

trans-unit.source: Upgrading Web or Business databases to a new service tier/performance level does not take the database offline.
trans-unit.target: Upgrading Web or Business databases to a new service tier/performance level does not take the database offline.

trans-unit.source: The database will continue to work through the upgrade operation.
trans-unit.target: The database will continue to work through the upgrade operation.

trans-unit.source: At the time of the actual transition to the new performance level temporary dropping of the connections to the database can happen for a very small duration (typically measured in seconds).
trans-unit.target: At the time of the actual transition to the new performance level temporary dropping of the connections to the database can happen for a very small duration (typically measured in seconds).

trans-unit.source: If an application has transient fault handling for connection terminations then it is sufficient to protect against dropped connections at the end of the upgrade.
trans-unit.target: If an application has transient fault handling for connection terminations then it is sufficient to protect against dropped connections at the end of the upgrade.

trans-unit.source: Upgrading a Web or Business database to a new service tier involves the following steps:
trans-unit.target: Upgrading a Web or Business database to a new service tier involves the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Determine service tier based on feature capability
trans-unit.target: Determine service tier based on feature capability

trans-unit.source: Determine an acceptable performance level based on historical resource usage
trans-unit.target: Determine an acceptable performance level based on historical resource usage

trans-unit.source: Why does existing performance for my Web or Business database map to the higher Premium levels?
trans-unit.target: Why does existing performance for my Web or Business database map to the higher Premium levels?

trans-unit.source: Tuning your workload to fit a lower performance level
trans-unit.target: Tuning your workload to fit a lower performance level

trans-unit.source: Upgrade to the new service tier/performance level
trans-unit.target: Upgrade to the new service tier/performance level

trans-unit.source: Monitor the upgrade to the new service tier/performance level
trans-unit.target: Monitor the upgrade to the new service tier/performance level

trans-unit.source: Monitor the database after the upgrade
trans-unit.target: Monitor the database after the upgrade

trans-unit.source: The Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers offer differing feature sets, so the first step in selecting an appropriate tier is to determine the service tier that provides the minimum level of feature capabilities required for your application and business.
trans-unit.target: The Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers offer differing feature sets, so the first step in selecting an appropriate tier is to determine the service tier that provides the minimum level of feature capabilities required for your application and business.

trans-unit.source: For example, consider how long backups need to be retained, or if <linkText>Standard or Active Geo-Replication</linkText><title></title> features are needed, or the overall maximum database size needed, etc. These requirements determine your minimum service tier choice.
trans-unit.target: For example, consider how long backups need to be retained, or if <linkText>Standard or Active Geo-Replication</linkText><title></title> features are needed, or the overall maximum database size needed, etc. These requirements determine your minimum service tier choice.

trans-unit.source: The ‘Basic’ tier is primarily used for very small, low activity databases.
trans-unit.target: The ‘Basic’ tier is primarily used for very small, low activity databases.

trans-unit.source: So, for an upgrade you should usually start with the ‘Standard’ or ‘Premium’ tier based on the minimum level of required features.
trans-unit.target: So, for an upgrade you should usually start with the ‘Standard’ or ‘Premium’ tier based on the minimum level of required features.

trans-unit.source: The new service tier's features and performance levels are summarized and compared in the following table:
trans-unit.target: The new service tier's features and performance levels are summarized and compared in the following table:

trans-unit.source: Additional resources for comparing service tiers and performance levels:
trans-unit.target: Additional resources for comparing service tiers and performance levels:

trans-unit.source: Article
trans-unit.target: Article

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Service Tiers (Editions)</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Service Tiers (Editions)</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Overview of the Basic, Standard, and Premium Service Tiers.
trans-unit.target: Overview of the Basic, Standard, and Premium Service Tiers.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Service Tiers and Performance Levels</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Service Tiers and Performance Levels</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Metrics and capabilities for each service tier (and how to monitor database utilization in the management portal and by using DMVs).
trans-unit.target: Metrics and capabilities for each service tier (and how to monitor database utilization in the management portal and by using DMVs).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>What is Different in the Service Tiers?</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>What is Different in the Service Tiers?</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: More information about the different service tiers including some reasons why you would select one tier over another.
trans-unit.target: More information about the different service tiers including some reasons why you would select one tier over another.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Business Continuity</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Business Continuity</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Details of the business continuity and disaster recovery features (point-in-time restore, geo-restore, geo-replication) available for the different service tiers.
trans-unit.target: Details of the business continuity and disaster recovery features (point-in-time restore, geo-restore, geo-replication) available for the different service tiers.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL Database Pricing</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL Database Pricing</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Detailed pricing information for the different service tiers and performance levels.
trans-unit.target: Detailed pricing information for the different service tiers and performance levels.

trans-unit.source: After selecting an appropriate service tier that satisfies the requirements for your database, the next step is to select a performance level that is acceptable for your actual database workloads.
trans-unit.target: After selecting an appropriate service tier that satisfies the requirements for your database, the next step is to select a performance level that is acceptable for your actual database workloads.

trans-unit.source: The Azure SQL Database service exposes information in the management portal, and in System Views, to provide you the suggested comparable new service tier and performance level for your existing Web or Business database.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SQL Database service exposes information in the management portal, and in System Views, to provide you the suggested comparable new service tier and performance level for your existing Web or Business database.

trans-unit.source: Since Web and Business databases do not have any guaranteed DTUs/resource limits associated with them, we normalize the percentage values in terms of the amount of resources available to an S2 performance level database.
trans-unit.target: Since Web and Business databases do not have any guaranteed DTUs/resource limits associated with them, we normalize the percentage values in terms of the amount of resources available to an S2 performance level database.

trans-unit.source: The average DTU percentage consumption of a database at any specific interval can be calculated as the highest percentage value among CPU, IO and Log usage at that interval.
trans-unit.target: The average DTU percentage consumption of a database at any specific interval can be calculated as the highest percentage value among CPU, IO and Log usage at that interval.

trans-unit.source: Use the management portal for a high-level overview of DTU percentage usage, and then drill into the details using system views.
trans-unit.target: Use the management portal for a high-level overview of DTU percentage usage, and then drill into the details using system views.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the new Azure management portal to view the recommended service tier for your Web or Business database when you upgrade a server to Azure SQL Database V12 (<linkText>at preview in some regions</linkText><title></title>).
trans-unit.target: You can also use the new Azure management portal to view the recommended service tier for your Web or Business database when you upgrade a server to Azure SQL Database V12 (<linkText>at preview in some regions</linkText><title></title>).

trans-unit.source: The management portal recommends the appropriate service tier for your Web or Business database during the process of upgrading a server to Azure SQL Database V12.
trans-unit.target: The management portal recommends the appropriate service tier for your Web or Business database during the process of upgrading a server to Azure SQL Database V12.

trans-unit.source: The recommendation is based on a historical analysis of the resource consumption of the database.
trans-unit.target: The recommendation is based on a historical analysis of the resource consumption of the database.

trans-unit.source: New Management Portal
trans-unit.target: New Management Portal

trans-unit.source: Log on to the <linkText>new management portal</linkText><title></title> and navigate to a server containing a Web or Business database.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the <linkText>new management portal</linkText><title></title> and navigate to a server containing a Web or Business database.

trans-unit.source: Click the Latest Update part in the server blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Latest Update part in the server blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Upgrade this server.
trans-unit.target: Click Upgrade this server.

trans-unit.source: The Upgrade this server blade now shows a list of Web or Business databases on the server along with the recommended service tier.
trans-unit.target: The Upgrade this server blade now shows a list of Web or Business databases on the server along with the recommended service tier.

trans-unit.source: The management portal provides insight into the DTU consumption for an existing Web or Business database.
trans-unit.target: The management portal provides insight into the DTU consumption for an existing Web or Business database.

trans-unit.source: DTU information is available in the current Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: DTU information is available in the current Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Management Portal

trans-unit.source: Log on to the <linkText>management portal</linkText><title></title> and navigate to an existing Web or Business database.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the <linkText>management portal</linkText><title></title> and navigate to an existing Web or Business database.

trans-unit.source: Click the MONITOR tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the MONITOR tab.

trans-unit.source: Click ADD METRICS.
trans-unit.target: Click ADD METRICS.

trans-unit.source: Select DTU percentage and click the checkmark at bottom to confirm.
trans-unit.target: Select DTU percentage and click the checkmark at bottom to confirm.

trans-unit.source: After confirming you should see the DTU percentage data in the table.
trans-unit.target: After confirming you should see the DTU percentage data in the table.

trans-unit.source: Remember, this is percentage as compared to DTUs in a Standard(S2) level database, which is 50 DTUs.
trans-unit.target: Remember, this is percentage as compared to DTUs in a Standard(S2) level database, which is 50 DTUs.

trans-unit.source: Also worth noting is that this data is the average of samples that are taken every 5 minutes, so there can be short bursts of activity between samples that are not reflected in these metrics.
trans-unit.target: Also worth noting is that this data is the average of samples that are taken every 5 minutes, so there can be short bursts of activity between samples that are not reflected in these metrics.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>DTU percentage data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>DTU percentage data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Notice the data in the example above shows an average usage of approximately 10 DTUs (19.23% of 50) and a max DTU percentage of ~28 DTUs (55.83% x 50).
trans-unit.target: Notice the data in the example above shows an average usage of approximately 10 DTUs (19.23% of 50) and a max DTU percentage of ~28 DTUs (55.83% x 50).

trans-unit.source: Assuming this data represented my typical workload I would likely select Standard(S1) for my initial upgrade.
trans-unit.target: Assuming this data represented my typical workload I would likely select Standard(S1) for my initial upgrade.

trans-unit.source: Standard(S0) provides 10 DTUs which is my average usage but that would mean my database would on average be running 100% capacity, which is never a good plan.
trans-unit.target: Standard(S0) provides 10 DTUs which is my average usage but that would mean my database would on average be running 100% capacity, which is never a good plan.

trans-unit.source: While S1 would likely be a good choice for my average usage, what about the times I'm hitting the MAX?
trans-unit.target: While S1 would likely be a good choice for my average usage, what about the times I'm hitting the MAX?

trans-unit.source: Maybe I know the spikes are from some overnight maintenance process, and actual customer usage is not impacted, I might be okay with reduced performance during that timeframe.
trans-unit.target: Maybe I know the spikes are from some overnight maintenance process, and actual customer usage is not impacted, I might be okay with reduced performance during that timeframe.

trans-unit.source: But maybe I don't know when the MAX is being hit so the DTU percentage consumption may require further analysis.
trans-unit.target: But maybe I don't know when the MAX is being hit so the DTU percentage consumption may require further analysis.

trans-unit.source: To drill into the details of a database's resource consumption you can use the provided System Views.
trans-unit.target: To drill into the details of a database's resource consumption you can use the provided System Views.

trans-unit.source: Web and Business database resource consumption data is accessed through the <linkText>sys.resource_stats</linkText><title></title> view in the master database of the logical server where your current database is located.
trans-unit.target: Web and Business database resource consumption data is accessed through the <linkText>sys.resource_stats</linkText><title></title> view in the master database of the logical server where your current database is located.

trans-unit.source: It displays resource consumption data in percentages of the limit of the performance level.
trans-unit.target: It displays resource consumption data in percentages of the limit of the performance level.

trans-unit.source: This view provides data for up to the last 14 days, at 5 minute intervals.
trans-unit.target: This view provides data for up to the last 14 days, at 5 minute intervals.

trans-unit.source: You can now use the [sys.dmdbresource_stats](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn800981.aspx) view in Web and Business databases for a higher granularity view (every 15 seconds) of resource consumption data.
trans-unit.target: You can now use the [sys.dmdbresource_stats](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn800981.aspx) view in Web and Business databases for a higher granularity view (every 15 seconds) of resource consumption data.

trans-unit.source: Because sys.dmdbresource_stats only retains historical data for one hour you can query this DMV every hour and store the data for additional analysis.
trans-unit.target: Because sys.dmdbresource_stats only retains historical data for one hour you can query this DMV every hour and store the data for additional analysis.

trans-unit.source: Run the following query on the master database to retrieve the average DTU consumption for a database:
trans-unit.target: Run the following query on the master database to retrieve the average DTU consumption for a database:

trans-unit.source: The data returned by [sys.resourcestats](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn269979.aspx) and [sys.dmdbresourcestats](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn800981.aspx) for Web and Business tiers indicate the percentages in terms of the Standard S2 performance tier.
trans-unit.target: The data returned by [sys.resourcestats](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn269979.aspx) and [sys.dmdbresourcestats](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn800981.aspx) for Web and Business tiers indicate the percentages in terms of the Standard S2 performance tier.

trans-unit.source: For example, when executing against a Web or Business database, if values return 70%, that indicates 70% of the S2 tier limit.
trans-unit.target: For example, when executing against a Web or Business database, if values return 70%, that indicates 70% of the S2 tier limit.

trans-unit.source: In addition, for Web and Business, the percentages may reflect numbers in excess of 100%, which is also based on the S2 tier limit.
trans-unit.target: In addition, for Web and Business, the percentages may reflect numbers in excess of 100%, which is also based on the S2 tier limit.

trans-unit.source: DTU consumption information in terms of an S2 database level allows you to normalize the current consumption of your Web and Business databases in terms of new tier databases and see where they fit better.
trans-unit.target: DTU consumption information in terms of an S2 database level allows you to normalize the current consumption of your Web and Business databases in terms of new tier databases and see where they fit better.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your average DTU percentage consumption shows a value of 80%, it indicates that the database is consuming DTU at the rate of 80% of the limit of a database at S2 performance level.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your average DTU percentage consumption shows a value of 80%, it indicates that the database is consuming DTU at the rate of 80% of the limit of a database at S2 performance level.

trans-unit.source: If you see values greater than 100% in the sys.resource_stats view, it means that you need a performance tier larger than S2.
trans-unit.target: If you see values greater than 100% in the sys.resource_stats view, it means that you need a performance tier larger than S2.

trans-unit.source: As an example, let’s say you see a peak DTU percentage value of 300%.
trans-unit.target: As an example, let’s say you see a peak DTU percentage value of 300%.

trans-unit.source: This tells you that you are using three times more resources than would be available in an S2.
trans-unit.target: This tells you that you are using three times more resources than would be available in an S2.

trans-unit.source: To determine a reasonable starting size, compare the DTUs available in an S2 (50 DTUs) with the next higher sizes (S3/P1 = 100 DTUs, or 200% of S2, P2 = 200 DTUs or 400% of S2).
trans-unit.target: To determine a reasonable starting size, compare the DTUs available in an S2 (50 DTUs) with the next higher sizes (S3/P1 = 100 DTUs, or 200% of S2, P2 = 200 DTUs or 400% of S2).

trans-unit.source: Because you are at 300% of S2 you may want to start with a P2 and re-test.
trans-unit.target: Because you are at 300% of S2 you may want to start with a P2 and re-test.

trans-unit.source: Based on the DTU usage percent and the largest edition that was required to fit your workload, you can determine which service tier and performance level is best suited for your database workload (as indicated through DTU percentage and relative DTU powers of various <linkText>performance levels)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Based on the DTU usage percent and the largest edition that was required to fit your workload, you can determine which service tier and performance level is best suited for your database workload (as indicated through DTU percentage and relative DTU powers of various <linkText>performance levels)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Here is a table that provides a mapping of the Web/Business resource consumption percentage to equivalent new tier performance levels:
trans-unit.target: Here is a table that provides a mapping of the Web/Business resource consumption percentage to equivalent new tier performance levels:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Resource consumption</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Resource consumption</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note: Relative DTU numbers between various performance levels are based on the Azure SQL Database Benchmark workload.
trans-unit.target: Note: Relative DTU numbers between various performance levels are based on the Azure SQL Database Benchmark workload.

trans-unit.source: Since your database’s workload is likely to be different from the benchmark, you should use the above calculations as the guideline for an initial fit for your Web/Business database in the new tiers.
trans-unit.target: Since your database’s workload is likely to be different from the benchmark, you should use the above calculations as the guideline for an initial fit for your Web/Business database in the new tiers.

trans-unit.source: Once you have moved the database to the new tier, use the process outlined in the previous section to validate/fine tune the right service tier that fits your workload needs.
trans-unit.target: Once you have moved the database to the new tier, use the process outlined in the previous section to validate/fine tune the right service tier that fits your workload needs.

trans-unit.source: While the suggested new edition tier/performance level takes into consideration your database activity over the last 14 days, this data is based on resource consumption data samples averaged over 5 minutes.
trans-unit.target: While the suggested new edition tier/performance level takes into consideration your database activity over the last 14 days, this data is based on resource consumption data samples averaged over 5 minutes.

trans-unit.source: As such it can miss short term bursts of activity that are shorter than 5 minutes in duration.
trans-unit.target: As such it can miss short term bursts of activity that are shorter than 5 minutes in duration.

trans-unit.source: So, this guidance should be used as a starting point to upgrade your database to.
trans-unit.target: So, this guidance should be used as a starting point to upgrade your database to.

trans-unit.source: Once you upgrade the database to the suggested tier, more monitoring, testing and validations are needed and the database can be moved Up/down to a different tier/performance level as needed.
trans-unit.target: Once you upgrade the database to the suggested tier, more monitoring, testing and validations are needed and the database can be moved Up/down to a different tier/performance level as needed.

trans-unit.source: Here is a query on the master database that performs the calculation for your Web/Business tier database and suggests which edition is likely to fit your workload for each of these 5 minute data sample intervals.
trans-unit.target: Here is a query on the master database that performs the calculation for your Web/Business tier database and suggests which edition is likely to fit your workload for each of these 5 minute data sample intervals.

trans-unit.source: Note: This query is useful only for Web/Business databases and will not give correct results for databases in the new tiers.
trans-unit.target: Note: This query is useful only for Web/Business databases and will not give correct results for databases in the new tiers.

trans-unit.source: Sample result:
trans-unit.target: Sample result:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Sample Result</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Sample Result</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Graphed you can see the trend of average DTU percentage consumption over time.
trans-unit.target: Graphed you can see the trend of average DTU percentage consumption over time.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example graph for a database that is in within an S2 level most of the time, with some peak activity shooting up to a P1 database level.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example graph for a database that is in within an S2 level most of the time, with some peak activity shooting up to a P1 database level.

trans-unit.source: DTU consumption over time varies from ‘Basic’ limits up to ‘P1’ limits.
trans-unit.target: DTU consumption over time varies from ‘Basic’ limits up to ‘P1’ limits.

trans-unit.source: To fully fit this database in the new tier, you will need a Premium service tier database with ‘P1’ performance level.
trans-unit.target: To fully fit this database in the new tier, you will need a Premium service tier database with ‘P1’ performance level.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, an S2 level database can work if these occasional bursts to P1 level are rare.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, an S2 level database can work if these occasional bursts to P1 level are rare.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>DTU Usage</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>DTU Usage</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Memory impact on performance: Although memory is one of the resource dimensions that contributes to the DTU rating, SQL Database is designed to use all available memory for database operations.
trans-unit.target: Memory impact on performance: Although memory is one of the resource dimensions that contributes to the DTU rating, SQL Database is designed to use all available memory for database operations.

trans-unit.source: For this reason memory consumption is not included in the average DTU consumption in the above query.
trans-unit.target: For this reason memory consumption is not included in the average DTU consumption in the above query.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, if you are downsizing to a lower performance level, then available memory for the database is reduced.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, if you are downsizing to a lower performance level, then available memory for the database is reduced.

trans-unit.source: This can result in higher IO consumption affecting DTU consumed.
trans-unit.target: This can result in higher IO consumption affecting DTU consumed.

trans-unit.source: So, when downsizing to a lower performance level, make sure that you have enough headroom in the IO percentage.
trans-unit.target: So, when downsizing to a lower performance level, make sure that you have enough headroom in the IO percentage.

trans-unit.source: Use <linkText>sys.dm_ db_ resource_stats</linkText><title></title> DMV mentioned above to monitor this.
trans-unit.target: Use <linkText>sys.dm_ db_ resource_stats</linkText><title></title> DMV mentioned above to monitor this.

trans-unit.source: Web and Business databases have no specific amount of resource capacity reserved for any individual database.
trans-unit.target: Web and Business databases have no specific amount of resource capacity reserved for any individual database.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, there is no mechanism in place for customers to scale performance up or down for a Web or Business database.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, there is no mechanism in place for customers to scale performance up or down for a Web or Business database.

trans-unit.source: This results in Web and Business database performance ranging anywhere from agonizingly slow up to Premium levels.
trans-unit.target: This results in Web and Business database performance ranging anywhere from agonizingly slow up to Premium levels.

trans-unit.source: This varying range of performance is unfairly dependent on the overall level of resource consumption at any point in time by other databases within the multi-tenant environment that share resources.
trans-unit.target: This varying range of performance is unfairly dependent on the overall level of resource consumption at any point in time by other databases within the multi-tenant environment that share resources.

trans-unit.source: Of course the Azure SQL Database services' goal is to have all Web and Business databases run as close to 100% optimal as possible.
trans-unit.target: Of course the Azure SQL Database services' goal is to have all Web and Business databases run as close to 100% optimal as possible.

trans-unit.source: And they’ve done a great job of keeping average performance levels of Web and Business databases upwards of Premium levels.
trans-unit.target: And they’ve done a great job of keeping average performance levels of Web and Business databases upwards of Premium levels.

trans-unit.source: This is why your existing database's performance might map to current Premium levels.
trans-unit.target: This is why your existing database's performance might map to current Premium levels.

trans-unit.source: Unfortunately this has resulted in somewhat unrealistic expectations when comparing Web and Business databases to the new service tiers/performance levels when assessing what service tier to upgrade to.
trans-unit.target: Unfortunately this has resulted in somewhat unrealistic expectations when comparing Web and Business databases to the new service tiers/performance levels when assessing what service tier to upgrade to.

trans-unit.source: To more clearly understand the differences between Web/Business and the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers, lets look at the picture below.
trans-unit.target: To more clearly understand the differences between Web/Business and the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers, lets look at the picture below.

trans-unit.source: Consider 9 SQL Databases running in the shared-resource Web/Business model compared to 9 SQL Databases running in the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tier model.
trans-unit.target: Consider 9 SQL Databases running in the shared-resource Web/Business model compared to 9 SQL Databases running in the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tier model.

trans-unit.source: In the Web/Business model you can clearly see the effects that 'noisy neighbors' have on the other databases that are participating in this shared-resource pool.
trans-unit.target: In the Web/Business model you can clearly see the effects that 'noisy neighbors' have on the other databases that are participating in this shared-resource pool.

trans-unit.source: When 1 database is running a resource intensive workload, all the other databases in the pool are affected and the available resources start to diminish.
trans-unit.target: When 1 database is running a resource intensive workload, all the other databases in the pool are affected and the available resources start to diminish.

trans-unit.source: In the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers a specific amount of resources *are* allocated for each database so other databases within the shared environment are essentially isolated from the noisy neighbor issue and bound by the performance level selected for the database.
trans-unit.target: In the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers a specific amount of resources *are* allocated for each database so other databases within the shared environment are essentially isolated from the noisy neighbor issue and bound by the performance level selected for the database.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Predictable performance of the new service tiers</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Predictable performance of the new service tiers</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If your overall DTU percentage is extremely high, you should start looking into the detailed metrics that the DTUs are comprised of; specifically drilling into the finer details of the database’s Log I/O and memory usage.
trans-unit.target: If your overall DTU percentage is extremely high, you should start looking into the detailed metrics that the DTUs are comprised of; specifically drilling into the finer details of the database’s Log I/O and memory usage.

trans-unit.source: It may uncover potential areas where you can optimize and reduce DTU consumption.
trans-unit.target: It may uncover potential areas where you can optimize and reduce DTU consumption.

trans-unit.source: If the analysis of your database's historical resource usage indicates that you should upgrade to a performance level that is more costly than you would like, you can look into areas where additional performance tuning may help.
trans-unit.target: If the analysis of your database's historical resource usage indicates that you should upgrade to a performance level that is more costly than you would like, you can look into areas where additional performance tuning may help.

trans-unit.source: Considering your knowledge regarding the details of your application, if the resource usage seems extremely high compared to what you expect the typical workload should be, then perhaps you have some opportunities where performance tuning can benefit your application.
trans-unit.target: Considering your knowledge regarding the details of your application, if the resource usage seems extremely high compared to what you expect the typical workload should be, then perhaps you have some opportunities where performance tuning can benefit your application.

trans-unit.source: In reality, all databases can benefit from another round of performance tuning.
trans-unit.target: In reality, all databases can benefit from another round of performance tuning.

trans-unit.source: In addition to the typical tuning maintenance such as analyzing indexes, execution plans, etc., you should optimize your data access routines to target Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the typical tuning maintenance such as analyzing indexes, execution plans, etc., you should optimize your data access routines to target Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Article
trans-unit.target: Article

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Performance Guidance</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Performance Guidance</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: The 'Tuning Your Application' section provides detailed recommendations and techniques for performance tuning an Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The 'Tuning Your Application' section provides detailed recommendations and techniques for performance tuning an Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Performance Monitoring and Tuning Tools</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Performance Monitoring and Tuning Tools</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Links and descriptions of the available tools for monitoring events in SQL Server and for tuning the physical database design.
trans-unit.target: Links and descriptions of the available tools for monitoring events in SQL Server and for tuning the physical database design.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Monitor and Tune for Performance</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Monitor and Tune for Performance</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: SQL Server 2014 performance tuning section on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server 2014 performance tuning section on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Troubleshooting Performance Problems in SQL Server 2008</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Troubleshooting Performance Problems in SQL Server 2008</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Older but still relevant whitepaper providing guidance for troubleshooting common performance problems, including great information on troubleshooting memory and cpu bottlenecks.
trans-unit.target: Older but still relevant whitepaper providing guidance for troubleshooting common performance problems, including great information on troubleshooting memory and cpu bottlenecks.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Troubleshoot and Optimize Queries with Azure SQL Database</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Troubleshoot and Optimize Queries with Azure SQL Database</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Older but still relevant topic on Dynamic Management Views and how they can be used for troubleshooting purposes.
trans-unit.target: Older but still relevant topic on Dynamic Management Views and how they can be used for troubleshooting purposes.

trans-unit.source: After you determine the appropriate service tier and performance level for your Web or Business database, there are multiple ways to upgrade the database to the new tier:
trans-unit.target: After you determine the appropriate service tier and performance level for your Web or Business database, there are multiple ways to upgrade the database to the new tier:

trans-unit.source: Management Tool
trans-unit.target: Management Tool

trans-unit.source: To change the service tier and performance level of a database
trans-unit.target: To change the service tier and performance level of a database

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: click the SCALE tab on your database's dashboard page.
trans-unit.target: click the SCALE tab on your database's dashboard page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: use the <linkText>Set-AzureSqlDatabase</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: use the <linkText>Set-AzureSqlDatabase</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Service Management REST API</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Service Management REST API</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: use the <linkText>Update Database</linkText><title></title> command.
trans-unit.target: use the <linkText>Update Database</linkText><title></title> command.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Transact-SQL</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Transact-SQL</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: use the <linkText>ALTER DATABASE (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title> statement.
trans-unit.target: use the <linkText>ALTER DATABASE (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title> statement.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <linkText>Changing Database Service Tiers and Performance Levels</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For details, see <linkText>Changing Database Service Tiers and Performance Levels</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database provides progress information on management operations (like CREATE, ALTER, DROP) performed on a database in the sys.dmoperationstatus dynamic management view in the master database of the logical server where your current database is located see sys.dm _operation _status documentation. Use the operation status DMV to determine progress of the upgrade operation for a database.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database provides progress information on management operations (like CREATE, ALTER, DROP) performed on a database in the sys.dmoperationstatus dynamic management view in the master database of the logical server where your current database is located see sys.dm _operation _status documentation. Use the operation status DMV to determine progress of the upgrade operation for a database.

trans-unit.source: This sample query shows all of the management operations performed on a database:
trans-unit.target: This sample query shows all of the management operations performed on a database:

trans-unit.source: If you used the management portal for the upgrade, a notification is also available from within the portal for the operation.
trans-unit.target: If you used the management portal for the upgrade, a notification is also available from within the portal for the operation.

trans-unit.source: Performance levels are calibrated and governed to provide the needed resources to run your database workload up to the max limits allowed for your selected service tier/performance level (i.e. resource consumption is at 100%).
trans-unit.target: Performance levels are calibrated and governed to provide the needed resources to run your database workload up to the max limits allowed for your selected service tier/performance level (i.e. resource consumption is at 100%).

trans-unit.source: If your workload is hitting the limits in one of CPU/Data IO/Log IO limits, you will continue to receive the resources at the maximum allowed level, but you are likely to see increased latencies for your queries.
trans-unit.target: If your workload is hitting the limits in one of CPU/Data IO/Log IO limits, you will continue to receive the resources at the maximum allowed level, but you are likely to see increased latencies for your queries.

trans-unit.source: Hitting one of these limits will not result in any errors, but just a slowdown in your workload, unless the slowdown becomes so severe that queries start timing out.
trans-unit.target: Hitting one of these limits will not result in any errors, but just a slowdown in your workload, unless the slowdown becomes so severe that queries start timing out.

trans-unit.source: If you are hitting limits of maximum allowed concurrent user sessions/requests (worker threads), you will see <linkText>error 10928 or 10929</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you are hitting limits of maximum allowed concurrent user sessions/requests (worker threads), you will see <linkText>error 10928 or 10929</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: After upgrade of the Web/Business database into the new tier, it is recommended to monitor the database actively to ensure applications are running at the desired performance and optimize usage as needed.
trans-unit.target: After upgrade of the Web/Business database into the new tier, it is recommended to monitor the database actively to ensure applications are running at the desired performance and optimize usage as needed.

trans-unit.source: The following additional steps are recommended for monitoring the database.
trans-unit.target: The following additional steps are recommended for monitoring the database.

trans-unit.source: Resource consumption data: For Basic, Standard, and Premium databases more granular resource consumption data is available through a new DMV called sys.dm_ db_ resource_stats in the user database. This DMV provides near real time resource consumption information at 15 second granularity for the previous hour of operation. The DTU percentage consumption for an interval is computed as the maximum percentage consumption of the CPU, IO & log dimensions. Here is a query to compute the average DTU percentage consumption over the last hour:
trans-unit.target: Resource consumption data: For Basic, Standard, and Premium databases more granular resource consumption data is available through a new DMV called sys.dm_ db_ resource_stats in the user database. This DMV provides near real time resource consumption information at 15 second granularity for the previous hour of operation. The DTU percentage consumption for an interval is computed as the maximum percentage consumption of the CPU, IO & log dimensions. Here is a query to compute the average DTU percentage consumption over the last hour:

trans-unit.source: Additional <linkText>documentation</linkText><title></title> contains details of how to use this DMV.
trans-unit.target: Additional <linkText>documentation</linkText><title></title> contains details of how to use this DMV.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Performance Guidance</linkText><title></title> covers how to monitor and tune your application.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure SQL Database Performance Guidance</linkText><title></title> covers how to monitor and tune your application.

trans-unit.source: Alerts: Set up 'Alerts' in the Azure Management Portal to notify you when the DTU consumption for an upgraded database approaches certain high level.
trans-unit.target: Alerts: Set up 'Alerts' in the Azure Management Portal to notify you when the DTU consumption for an upgraded database approaches certain high level.

trans-unit.source: Database alerts can be setup in the Azure Management Portal for various performance metrics like DTU, CPU, IO, and Log.
trans-unit.target: Database alerts can be setup in the Azure Management Portal for various performance metrics like DTU, CPU, IO, and Log.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can set up an email alert on “DTU Percentage” if the average DTU percentage value exceeds 75% over the last 5 minutes.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can set up an email alert on “DTU Percentage” if the average DTU percentage value exceeds 75% over the last 5 minutes.

trans-unit.source: Refer to <linkText>How to: Receive Alert Notifications and Manage Alert Rules in Azure</linkText><title></title> to learn more about how to configure alert notifications.
trans-unit.target: Refer to <linkText>How to: Receive Alert Notifications and Manage Alert Rules in Azure</linkText><title></title> to learn more about how to configure alert notifications.

trans-unit.source: Scheduled performance level upgrade/downgrade: If your application has specific scenarios that require more performance only at certain times of the day/week, you can use Azure Automation to upsize/downsize your database to a higher/lower performance level as a planned operation.
trans-unit.target: Scheduled performance level upgrade/downgrade: If your application has specific scenarios that require more performance only at certain times of the day/week, you can use Azure Automation to upsize/downsize your database to a higher/lower performance level as a planned operation.

trans-unit.source: For example, upgrade the database to a higher performance level for the duration of a weekly batch/maintenance job and downsize it after the job completes.
trans-unit.target: For example, upgrade the database to a higher performance level for the duration of a weekly batch/maintenance job and downsize it after the job completes.

trans-unit.source: This kind of scheduling is also useful for any large resource-intensive operations like data loading, index rebuilding etc. Note that the Azure SQL Database billing model is based on hourly usage of a service tier/performance level.
trans-unit.target: This kind of scheduling is also useful for any large resource-intensive operations like data loading, index rebuilding etc. Note that the Azure SQL Database billing model is based on hourly usage of a service tier/performance level.

trans-unit.source: This flexibility allows you to plan for scheduled or planned upgrades more cost efficiently.
trans-unit.target: This flexibility allows you to plan for scheduled or planned upgrades more cost efficiently.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database service provides telemetry data and tools to evaluate your Web/Business database workloads and determine the best service tier fit for upgrade.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database service provides telemetry data and tools to evaluate your Web/Business database workloads and determine the best service tier fit for upgrade.

trans-unit.source: The upgrade process is quite simple and can be done without taking the database offline and with no data loss.
trans-unit.target: The upgrade process is quite simple and can be done without taking the database offline and with no data loss.

trans-unit.source: Upgraded databases benefit from the predictable performance and additional features provided by the new service tiers.
trans-unit.target: Upgraded databases benefit from the predictable performance and additional features provided by the new service tiers.
